definitions: put to practical use rather than remaining theoretical or abstract
having submitted a formal request or application for something
examples: She studied applied mathematics in college to solve real problems
The engineers focused on applied science rather than pure research
He's an applied candidate for the medical school program
Several applied students are waiting for their admission results

definitions: officially chosen or assigned to a position or task by authority
furnished, fitted out, or equipped with particular features or facilities
examples: The newly appointed director will start next Monday
She was appointed to lead the investigation committee
They stayed in a well appointed hotel with modern amenities
The beautifully appointed apartment had marble countertops

definitions: large or significant enough to be noticed, measured, or have an effect
examples: There was an appreciable difference in temperature between rooms
The company saw appreciable growth in sales last quarter
We noticed an appreciable improvement in her performance
The appreciable delay caused frustration among waiting passengers

definitions: recognized and valued for worth, quality, or significance by others
having risen or increased in monetary or material value over time
examples: Her hard work was finally appreciated by management
The appreciated employee received a promotion and bonus
The appreciated artwork sold for triple its original price
Their house has appreciated significantly over ten years

definitions: feeling or showing gratitude, thankfulness, or recognition of value
having the ability to understand, recognize, or judge quality and worth
examples: The appreciative audience gave a standing ovation
She sent an appreciative note thanking her mentor
He has an appreciative eye for fine art
Only appreciative listeners can truly enjoy classical music

definitions: seized and arrested by law enforcement or other authorities
understood, grasped, or perceived mentally with clarity or comprehension
examples: The apprehended suspect was taken to the police station
All apprehended individuals have the right to legal counsel
The apprehended concept finally made sense after explanation
Once apprehended, the theory seemed surprisingly simple

definitions: anxious or fearful that something bad or unpleasant will happen
examples: She felt apprehensive about starting her new job
The apprehensive student waited nervously for test results
Parents were apprehensive about the proposed school changes
He grew increasingly apprehensive as the deadline approached

definitions: friendly and easy to talk to without causing fear or hesitation
able to be reached, accessed, or dealt with without great difficulty
examples: The approachable professor encouraged students to ask questions
She has an approachable manner that puts people at ease
The summit is approachable from the eastern trail
This complex topic becomes approachable with proper explanation

definitions: coming nearer in distance, time, or amount
examples: The approaching storm forced everyone to seek shelter
With approaching deadlines, the team worked through weekends
Sales are approaching last year's record numbers
The approaching holiday season brought excitement to children

definitions: officially accepted, permitted, or agreed to by someone in authority
examples: The approved budget includes funding for new equipment
Only approved medications can be sold in pharmacies
Her approved vacation request starts next Monday
The committee reviewed all approved applications

definitions: showing or expressing agreement, acceptance, or favorable opinion
examples: She gave an approving nod during the presentation
His approving smile encouraged her to continue
The board cast approving votes for the proposal
Parents watched with approving eyes as children performed

definitions: close to the actual but not completely accurate or exact
examples: The approximate cost of repairs is five thousand dollars
Can you give me an approximate time of arrival?
These approximate figures should help with initial planning
The approximate distance between cities is 200 miles

definitions: having a tendency or likelihood to do something
quick to learn or understand things intelligently
appropriate or suitable in the circumstances
examples: She's apt to forget her keys when rushing
Children are apt to believe what adults tell them
The apt pupil mastered calculus before graduating
He proved an apt student of foreign languages
That's an apt description of the current situation
She made an apt comparison between the two events

definitions: relating to water or living in or near water
examples: Dolphins are aquatic mammals that breathe air
The aquatic center offers swimming and diving lessons
Many aquatic plants help maintain pond ecosystems
The museum features an extensive aquatic life exhibit

definitions: based on random choice or personal whim rather than reason or system
examples: The arbitrary decision upset many team members
Speed limits sometimes seem arbitrary but serve safety purposes
His arbitrary rules made no logical sense
The teacher's arbitrary grading system frustrated students

definitions: understood by few; mysterious or secret knowledge known only to the initiated
examples: The professor explained arcane mathematical theories
Ancient texts contained arcane symbols and meanings
Computer programming seemed arcane to the beginner
The club's arcane rituals puzzled outside observers

definitions: chief, principal, or most important in rank or position
playfully teasing or mischievous in manner or tone
examples: He was her arch rival in the competition
The arch villain appeared in the final scene
She gave him an arch look before revealing the surprise
His arch comments always made the class laugh

definitions: relating to the study of human history through excavation and analysis of artifacts
examples: The archaeological dig uncovered ancient pottery fragments
Archaeological evidence suggests the city is 3000 years old
She joined an archaeological expedition to Egypt
The museum displays archaeological finds from local sites

definitions: very old or old-fashioned; no longer in everyday use
examples: The document contained archaic language difficult to understand
Some consider handwritten letters archaic in the digital age
The archaic laws were finally updated last year
He used archaic words that confused modern readers

definitions: having a curved shape like an arch or bow
examples: The cat's arched back showed it felt threatened
The bridge had beautifully arched stone supports
She raised one arched eyebrow in surprise
The arched doorway led into the ancient cathedral

definitions: representing the most typical or perfect example of a particular kind
examples: He's the archetypal mad scientist with wild hair
The story follows an archetypal hero's journey pattern
She played the archetypal villain in the movie
Their cottage was archetypal English countryside architecture

definitions: forming or extending in a curve like an arch
examples: The arching branches created a natural canopy
Dolphins were arching through the waves
The arching rainbow stretched across the sky
Her arching movements in dance were graceful

definitions: relating to the design and construction of buildings and structures
examples: The architectural plans required city approval before construction
She studied architectural history at the university
The building's architectural features include Gothic arches
They hired an architectural firm to design their home

definitions: relating to or constituting archives or historical records and documents
examples: The archival footage showed events from 1945
Researchers used archival materials to write the biography
The library's archival collection includes rare manuscripts
Archival storage protects documents from deterioration

definitions: extremely cold like the conditions found in polar regions
relating to the regions around the North Pole
examples: The arctic wind made everyone shiver
We endured arctic temperatures during the blizzard
Arctic explorers face extreme weather conditions
The arctic fox has adapted to cold climates

definitions: showing strong feelings of passion, enthusiasm, or devotion
examples: She's an ardent supporter of environmental causes
His ardent love letters moved her to tears
The ardent fans waited hours for autographs
An ardent desire for justice motivated her work

definitions: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring
examples: The arduous climb to the summit took eight hours
Medical school is an arduous journey requiring dedication
After arduous negotiations, they reached an agreement
The arduous task of rebuilding began immediately

definitions: able to be argued about or open to disagreement and debate
examples: It's arguable whether the policy improved conditions
The movie's arguable status as a classic divides critics
His arguable claim needs more supporting evidence
The benefits of the program remain arguable

definitions: given to arguing or disposed to disagree and dispute with others
examples: The argumentative student challenged every point
Her argumentative nature made meetings last longer
He became argumentative when his ideas were questioned
The argumentative tone of the debate escalated quickly

definitions: having little or no rain; extremely dry and barren
lacking in interest, excitement, or meaning
examples: The arid desert receives less than ten inches of rain
Arid conditions make farming nearly impossible
The professor's arid lecture put students to sleep
The arid prose made the novel hard to finish

definitions: belonging to or typical of the aristocracy or nobility class
examples: Her aristocratic bearing commanded respect
The aristocratic family owned estates across Europe
He spoke with an aristocratic accent
The mansion had an aristocratic elegance

definitions: relating to arithmetic or the use of numbers in calculations
examples: Basic arithmetic skills include addition and subtraction
The arithmetic mean of the numbers is twelve
She made an arithmetic error in her calculations
Arithmetic progression follows a regular pattern

definitions: covered with protective armor plating or defensive covering
examples: The armored vehicle protected soldiers from attacks
Knights wore armored suits in medieval battles
The bank uses armored trucks to transport money
Armored cables prevent damage from external forces

definitions: having a pleasant and distinctive smell or fragrance
examples: The aromatic herbs filled the kitchen with fragrance
She added aromatic spices to the curry
Aromatic candles created a relaxing atmosphere
The aromatic flowers attracted bees and butterflies

definitions: awakened from sleep or stirred to action, emotion, or attention
examples: The loud noise aroused everyone from sleep
His curiosity was aroused by the mysterious package
The speech aroused strong feelings in the audience
Aroused suspicions led to further investigation

definitions: put in a neat, attractive, or organized order or position
planned, scheduled, or agreed upon beforehand between parties
examples: The flowers were beautifully arranged in the vase
Books were arranged alphabetically on the shelf
They had an arranged meeting at noon
Some cultures still practice arranged marriages

definitions: displayed or arranged in a particular and often impressive way
examples: The products were arrayed on shelves by color
Soldiers stood arrayed in perfect formation
Evidence was arrayed before the jury
The table was arrayed with delicious food

definitions: striking and attracting attention by being unusual or impressive
examples: Her arresting beauty stopped people in their tracks
The painting's arresting colors demanded attention
He had an arresting way of speaking
The arresting image became the magazine cover

definitions: having an exaggerated sense of one's importance or abilities
examples: His arrogant attitude alienated potential friends
The arrogant boss never listened to suggestions
She gave an arrogant dismissal of their concerns
Arrogant behavior often masks deep insecurity

definitions: relating to arteries or the tubes carrying blood from the heart
serving as a main route or channel like a major road
examples: The patient had arterial blockage requiring surgery
Arterial blood pressure was dangerously high
The arterial road connects major cities
This is an arterial route for commerce

definitions: showing creative skill or taste in design or execution
clever or skillful in a crafty or cunning way
examples: The artful arrangement of flowers impressed guests
Her artful photography captured emotion perfectly
He used artful persuasion to get his way
The child's artful excuses fooled no one

definitions: able to express thoughts and ideas clearly and effectively in speech
having joints or jointed segments allowing movement
examples: The articulate speaker explained complex ideas simply
She's very articulate for such a young child
The robot's articulate arm could grasp objects
Articulate skeletons help students learn anatomy

definitions: expressed or explained in clear and effective words
connected by joints allowing movement between rigid parts
examples: She articulated her concerns during the meeting
The well articulated argument convinced the jury
The articulated bus bends in the middle
An articulated toy figure can pose naturally

definitions: rising in power, influence, or importance; moving upward
examples: The ascendant political party won the election
Her career was clearly ascendant after the promotion
The ascendant sun brightened the morning sky
Youth culture was ascendant in the 1960s

definitions: moving upward or increasing in size, importance, or degree
examples: The ascending elevator reached the top floor
Numbers were arranged in ascending order
The ascending notes of the scale sounded clear
Smoke was ascending from the chimney

definitions: found out definitely or learned with certainty through investigation
examples: Police ascertained the facts through careful investigation
She ascertained that the information was accurate
Once ascertained, the truth shocked everyone
The ascertained cause of failure was mechanical

definitions: characterized by severe self-discipline and avoiding physical pleasures
examples: The monk lived an ascetic life in the monastery
Her ascetic diet consisted only of simple foods
The ascetic room contained just a bed
His ascetic lifestyle rejected material possessions

definitions: without sexual feelings or associations; not involving sexual reproduction
examples: Some organisms reproduce through asexual division
The asexual character wasn't interested in romance
Asexual reproduction creates identical offspring
She identified as asexual and aromantic

definitions: of a pale grayish color like ash or covered with ash
examples: His face turned ashy when he heard the news
The ashy residue covered everything after the fire
She applied lotion to her ashy skin
The volcano left an ashy coating on cars

definitions: not in a straight or level position; crooked or tilted
examples: The picture frame hung askew on the wall
His tie was askew after the long day
Her hat sat askew after the wind
The askew blinds let in streaks of light
